div1.p: Louise Kean provides news about yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from Louise Young Kean to Mrs. Mason Young, July 10, 1899
div1.opener:
Chief Surgeon's Office.
HEADQUARTERS SEVENTH ARMY CORPS.
Quemados - Cuba -
10th July 1899.
Dearest Mumsie-
div1.p:
Your letter of the
3rd came Saturday, and the
newspaper from father on the
same day. It is very good
of you to send each of
us something for our ward-
robe, and we shall appre-
ciate the things very much.
The list of the for me is
especially delightful, for it
just hits the things I
need most. I saw Major
Baker down town last
night and told him a
bundle was coming for me.
I asked him about the
package attatchment to
the transports, and he
said he did not know of
it. I have no doubt that
the people in New York
meant what they told
Mrs. Arthur on the subject,
but, as long as the Q.Ms-
at this end of the line
have not been told of it
I don't care to have them
feel they are doing me a
favor, so please have Helen
send my bundle by ex-
press. The rate to Havana
is very reasonable. 40¢ for one pound, and
then 5¢ added for each additional pound.
Address the package to Quemados, Havana,
and then we send in for it. If you have
a chance put in some bibs for Martha-

Isn't the news about the Clendenins
dreadfully sad. We have heard that Dr. C.
was sick four days, and died on the 4th of this
month. Our news of Mrs. C. and Miss Bessie
is very contradictory so that we feel we do
not know anything about them except that
they are in New York harbor, but as to whether
either or both have fever we can't make out
from the reports. At first we heard that
they were with Dr. C. when he died, but now
we think they must have left before. It
has made us all very blue and I cannot
but worry about Mrs. C. all the time- Col.
O'Reilly told Rannie yesterday that the epe-
demic was under control at Santiago. That is
a great relief, the poor doctors and hospital
corps men have had a terrible time down
there. Have I written you that Major
Brown is down with typhoid? He is quite
Chief Surgeon's Office.
HEADQUARTERS SEVENTH ARMY CORPS.
sick, for he had a walk-
ing case, and should have
gone to bed some time
before he did. Fitz Lee is
nearly well. Mrs. Jackson
who came down because her
husband had typhoid is
down with it herself now-
It is unfortunate, because
her coming was very un-
necessary, Dr. Jackson having
had the lightest case on
record.

Yesterday after lunch we
went in to town to see
the Ladds. They are living
at the Pyrotecnica Militare
which is on Principe hill
just between Vedado and the
city. They drove us down
to the Machina where we
found the Custom House
launch waiting for us.
We went over to Cabanas,
and while the men went
through that, Mrs. Ladd,
Katherine. Martha and I
sailed around the harbor.
Then we went to the
Luizo and had dinner-
Altho' we did not leave
town until the nine o'-
clock train Martha was
just as happy and good-
natured as any of us.

I have not seen Caz for a long time. We
did not go in to the Ludlows reception,
where I would probably have seen him, and
I telegraphed him not to come out yester-
day as we had the engagement with the
Ladds. Major Sturgis saw him at the Lud-
lows and said he seemed in his usual
good spirits. What do you suppose was the
object of Molly's attack on the poor young man?
Our weather is still lovely. I think the
mornings are hotter than they were last
month but in the house it is comfortable.
The rainy season still persists in refusing
to be a horror, it does not even rain every
day. Col. O'Reilly told Rannie some thing
very comforting yesterday so I hasten to im-
part it to you. He said that the records
show that in former years July was the
worst yellow fever month, there was a mark-
ed decrease in August, and only half as
many cases in September as in August. Here
we are well into July and only a couple of
cases in Havana. It is wonderful. I think
Chief Surgeon's Office.
HEADQUARTERS SEVENTH ARMY CORPS.
the doctors feel that even
if there is an epedemic
in the city it can be
kept from Quemados, and
from the troops out here.
The Cuban doctors insist
that “yellow” is never found
in Quemados, which may
be true, but I don't think
any of us put much faith
in Cubanos, doctors or other-
wise. Don't you worry a-
bout me Mumsie, I am not
the only woman left in
Cuba. Our colony out here has
been increased by Mrs. Powers
of the cavalry. She is living
right across the street from
us, with a Cuban family.

I heard from Caz that
Helen had written me
about Bert's wedding. But
the letter has never come,
I am afraid the mails
are still rather unsafe-

Martha and Rannie
join me in much love
to you all
